item.title: EU Drugmakers to Report Growth and Earnings in 2014
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: According to Credit Suisse, EU drugmakers will report 4% sales growth and 6% earnings growth this year, as reported Monday in London South East. Bayer and Novartis will outperform the market, with Roche also doing well, although AstraZeneca and GlaxoSmithKline are likely to underperform.
Drug Categories in Focus
Credit Suisse suggested that drug categories such as cancer, respiratory, diabetes, cholesterol and haemophilia are likely to be in focus during 2014.
Emerging Markets
Following a tough year in emerging markets, Credit Suisse expects companies should benefit from a recovery in China and bounce back from company-specific shocks.
Source: FirstWord

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Auspex To IPO & Raise Up To $66m To Fund Huntington's Disease Development
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Auspex is aiming to IPO with a view to raising around $66m to fund the ongoing phIII development of its SD-809 a deuterated form of tetrabenazine for the treatment of involuntary movements associated with Huntington's disease.
SD-809 has pharmacokinetic properties that allow for more consistent blood levels and less frequent dosing (twice vs three times daily) compared to the marketed form of tetrabenazine, properties that may faciliated better compliance and outcomes.
Auspex started its phIII trial in July 2013 , a randomised double-blind placeob-controlled study in 90 patients who have not previously taken tetrabenazine. The study is being undertaken in combination with the Huntington Study Group, an international network of experienced clinical trial investiagators at leading academic centres that care for HD patients and their families.
Money raised from the new financing will also be used to fund a phII/III development of the drug in tardive dyskinesia and a phI study in Tourette's syndrome.
Source: www.auspexpharma.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: New NET Data to Emerge From ASCO GI 2014
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Two interesting trials were presented this weekend, one demonstrating the potential effectiveness of temozolomide/capecitabine in carcinoid patients progressive on Sandostatin LAR, the other highlighting the benefits of dose intensification of octreotide LAR to 40-60mg for symptom control in refractory NET patients. Additional to this was also an interesting overview of the NET treatment paradigm presented by Diane Lauren Reddy in a "Meet the Professor" Session, where it was acknowledged that RADIANT-4 is now complete and should report this year and that some interesting VEGF data is on the horizon.
Copies of both posters highlighted below are attached.
CAPTEM Data
Fine et al (Columbia University Medical Centre New York) have conducted a prospective single arm phII study in patients with progressive metastatic well differentiated NETs who had shown progression on 60mg Sandostatin LAR. These patients were treated with a 28 day cycle CAPTEM regimen (capecitabine/temzolomide). 28 patients have been treated so far including 12 with carcinoid tumours ( a group previously not recognised as responding to CAPTEM).
  • The primary objective was response rate based on RECIST & secondary objectives PFS, OS & toxicity.
  • The overall RR reported was 43% (11%CR & 32% PR).SD was 54% giving an overal CBR of 97%.
  • Interestingly, the ORR in the carcinoid gourp (typical and atypical patients) was 41% (8%CR & 33%PR). SD was 58% giving an overall CBR of 99%.
  • Ongoing PFS is >22mnths for all subtypes with ongoing OS >29.1mnths from the initiation of chemotherapy to death.
The authors make the point that CAPTEM appears to be an effective regiment for patients with metastatic NETS progressing on higher doses of Sandostatin. In comparison the phIII trials with everolimus and Sutent had a mPFS or 11 months and 11,4 months respectively and both had RR of <10%.
Higher Dose Octreotide Data
Efraija et al with the approval of the British Columbia Cancer Agency Ethics Committee retrospectively evaluated data for all patients receiving 60mg Octreotide LAR between 2005 and 2011, grading symptoms prior to and post any incremental dosage increase (DI). Pre and post ChGA and 5HIAA levels were also evaluated.
A total of 37 patients received DI therapy with 40mg (36), 50mg (3), 60mg (16) for a total of 55 DI events.
  • Tumour locality was small bowel (49%), pancreas (19%) and other (32%)
  • Post ChGA and 5HIAA levels decreased respectively in 31% and 23% of patients respectively
  • Symptom improvement post DI was 62% in patients with diarrhoea (13/21), 76% in patients with flushing (13/17) and 53% in those with abdominal pain (8/15).
Meet The Professor Session
The suprise findings in carcinoid patients was acknowledged by Diane Lauren Reddy in her "Meet The Professor" session on Neuroendocrine tumours. She commented on the small no of carcinoid patients evaluated and questioned the location of these tumours (details of which are unclear) and concluded that it remains to be seen the role of cytotocis chemotherapy for carcinoids.
Commenting on the higher dose SSA data, she suggested that there is an indication that incremental dosing may help to control symptoms but that currently no prospective data exists to support this.
Much of Diane Reddy's review focused on what is already known. However, she did acknowledge that the RADIANT-4 study is now complete and that the data this year should give us a more conclusive answer than RADIANT-2 on whether everolimus is effective for the treatment of mid-gut carcnoids.
Focusing in brief on "What is on the horizon" Reddy highlighted the following:-
  • the Lutathera trial;
  • a phII study that will be evaluating the role of everolimus as an adjuvant therapy in resected pNET which will be started very soon;
  • some potentially "exciting" data to emerge from some VEGF studies. PhII combination bevacizumab/temsirolimus data was referenced which at ASCO 2013 was shown to demonstrate a 37% ORR & a 6-month PFS of 80%, well in excess of single targeted agnets in pNET. The bevacizumab single-agent arm in this trial is currently accruing (NCT01010126). Secondly, Mathew Kulke's phII study evaluating everolimus & octreotide with or without bevacizumab in patients with locally advanced metastatic pNET has just completed (NCT01229943)
Source: ASCO GI 2014
  1. Fine CAPTEM Poster ASCO GI 2014.jpg  (4,5 MB)

item.title: Actavis Plans to Divest its EU Commercial Operations to Aurobindo
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Actavis announced that it intends to enter into an agreement to divest its generics commercial operations in France, Italy, Belgium (new territories for Aurobindo), Spain, Portugal, Germany and the Netherlands for approx €30M. Aurobindo reported that the deal would provide a "ready-made hospital sales infrastructure" for it to introduce its own injectable and specialty portfolio across Western Europe (The hospitals portfolio includes a number of injectables including oncology, pain management and anti infective therapies.
- Aurobindo to acquire Actavis' pharmaceutical commercial infrastructure in the 7 markets, including products, marketing authorisations and dossier license rights.
- The companies would also enter into a long-term strategic supply arrangement.
The acquisition will expand Aurobindo's front-end operations with about 1200 products (with more than 450 INNs) and 200 more in the works.
The company estimates the businesses acquired would record net sales of 320 million euros ($433 million) for 2013, growing at 10% YoY, and it expects the operations to turn profitable in combination with its vertically integrated platform.
Mix Business

item.title: Novel Three-Step Approach for a More Youthful Face
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In line with the desire of patients to achieve an overall youthful facial appearance, the authors report for the first time three cases where patients have been successfully treated across the whole face with a novel, three-step approach, layering Merz' Xeomin (incobotulinumtoxinA) and two dermal fillers (Radiesse/calcium hydroxylapatite and Belotero/a monophasic hyaluronic acid filler with CPM Technology) injected at three separate treatment visits.
Findings
The results suggest that this layering approach based on an understanding of the underlying causes of facial aging, where different products are used in combination to treat the entire face, can enable patients to achieve the desired outcome of a return to the characteristics of a more youthful face.
Reference

A novel, multistep, combination facial rejuvenation procedure for treatment of the whole face with incobotulinumtoxinA, and two dermal fillers- calcium hydroxylapatite and a monophasic, polydensified hyaluronic acid filler.

2013: Tatjana Pavicic; Julius W Few; Jurgen Huber-Vorländer - Journal of drugs in dermatology : JDD 2013;12(9):978-84.

item.title: Actavis Plans to Quit the China Market
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In an interview with Bloomberg News, CEO has cited an 'unfavorable business climate'. Management has reportedly sold one operation in China and is in talks to sell another. Eight months previously it announced it felt confident about prospects in China, with product launches in the country.
Actavis China
Actavis Foshan is an important manufacturing site in Asia. The Guangdong plant produces antibiotics and other products for use in the treatment of the digestive and cardiovascular system. Dosage forms include tablet, soft gel capsule, hard capsule, oral solution, dry suspension, ointments and liniments.

The Actavis (Foshan) Pharmaceutical Co., Ltd. is a joint venture between the Actavis Group and Foshan Chanbende Development Co., Ltd.
Major Shift for the Company
In May 2013, Actavis China President Gao Ren stated that the company was feeling confident about prospects in China, and that it would launch two new products annually, with the goal of launching 5-10 products annually by 2016.
Sales and Revenues Picture
The company generates annual profits in China of approx. USD 41.5 million.
Source: GBI

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Allergan Shares Rise As Patent-Cliff Worries Subside
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Allergan has received two pieces of good-news in one week. A Judge has upheld US patents covering the group's glaucoma treatment Lumigan and coincidentally the US Patent Office has issued Allergan with new protection for its lead opthalmic product Restasis. Morgan Stanley analysts have raised 2015-2020 EPS estimates by 15-20% as a result.
New Court Decision On Lumigan
Whilst generics are likely to appeal the appelate court decision is probably about 1-2 years ways. The U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Texas effectively affirmed all 5 patents covering Lumigan through 2027.
Allergan had sued several drugmakers looking to launch copies of the glaucoma drug's 0.1% formulation. That version in 2010 replaced a stronger solution that had caused temporary eye redness in some patients.

Allergan can keep its lock on the Lumigan market as long as at least one of the patents stays in place and that means keeping Lumigan's revenues, which totaled $622.6 million in 2012.

Restasis Patent

Alongside this verdict AGN announced its new patent on U.S. Restasis that expires in Aug. 2024 plus plans to submit a Citizen Petition in response to FDA’s draft guidance on generic Restasis.

Sources: www.allergan.com
Morgan Stanley report 15th January
Leerink & Swann report 14th January

item.title: Bayer's Radium-223 Dichloride + Abiraterone or Enzalutamide in CRPC Patient with Bone Mets
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: This newly reported Ph2a trial in clinicaltrials.gov is to assess safety and efficacy of the combination evaluated by rPFS (as a PE).
Recruitment: approx. 66
Timelines
  • Start date: January 2014
  • Comletion dates: Jan 2016 / Jan 2022
Trial Design
All patients involved in the study will be randomized into one of three arms:
  • radium-223 dichloride 50 kBq/kg administered every 4 weeks;
  • radium-223 dichloride 50 kBq/kg administered every 4 weeks together with abiraterone acetate 1000 mg orally daily plus prednisone 5 mg orally twice daily;
  • radium-223 dichloride 50 kBq/kg administered every 4 weeks together with enzalutamide 160 mg orally daily.
Location: USA
Source: NCT02034552

item.title: Results from Ph3 Pasireotide LAR vs Octreotide LAR in Medically Naïve Acromegalic Patients Just Published
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Data from the first of two PhIII with pasireotide in acromegaly has just been published in JCEM. The results highlight, as known, that a significantly better proportion of patients in the pasireotide LAR group achieved biochemical control (both GH and IGF1 criteria) compared with the octreotide LAR group (Primary Endpoint met). More details are provided below.
Pasireotide LAR demonstrates superiority over octreotide LAR in a prospective double-blind randomized 12-month study conducted in 358 medically naïve acromegalic patients.
Patients: They either had prior pituitary surgery but no medical treatment or were de novo.
Treatment: 176 patients received pasireotide LAR 40mg every 28 days and 182 patients received octreotide LAR 20mg every 28 days. Titration was permitted.
Main outcome measure: Proportion of patients in each treatment arm with biochemical control (GH < 2.5 microg / liter and normal IGF-1) at month 12.
Results: Biochemical control was achieved by significantly more pasireotide LAR patients than octreotide LAR patients (31.3% versus 19.2%; p=0.007; In pasireotide LAR and octreotide LAR patients, respectively, 38.6% and 23.6% ( p=0.002) achieved normal IGF-1, and 48.3% and 51.6% achieved GH < 2.5 microg / liter. In terms of tumour control, from baseline to month 12, mean tumour volume decreased by 40% and 38% respectively (p=0.838)
Safety: Hyperglycemia related adverse events were more common with pasireotide LAR (57.3% versus 21.7%).
  • Trial details http://clinicaltrials.gov/show/NCT00600886
  • Publication Reference http://press.endocrine.org/doi/pdf/10.1210/jc.2013-2480

New Deal To Focus On Increased Awareness & Adoption Of Intrathecal Therapies For Pain & Spasticity 
Comment: Medtronic and Mallinckrodt have entered into a multi-year agreement to advance the availability within the US of intrathecal therapeutics for the treatment of chronic pain and severe spasticity.  ...
Comment: Mallinckrodt's presentation late yesterday at the JP Morgan H/C conference, didn't focus particularly on the Medtronix deal but did note how Gablofen, a pre-filled syringe preparation for intrathecal administration for spasticity is now its no 2 lead product and how intrathecal product development will be part of its growth strategy. Gablofen was acquired through the purchase of CNS Therapeutics in September 2012.
Mark Trudeau CEO focused on his intention to grow the specialty part of the group's business and how the group's pipeline would support this growth. Mid-term this is focused on Xartemis XR a combination opioid product. Longer-term, the focus move to the potential within the intrathecal space. Whilst not specfied we have identified a CNS Therapeutics patent covering a new and improved versions of baclofen WO-2010090765-A2 which offers improved stability a lower concentrations of degredation products.
Longer-term coporate growth he suggested will also focus on BD&L opportunities in CNS in adjacent channels and therapeutics including neurology and orthopaedics.

item.title: Novartis' PI3K Inhibitor + Cabazitaxel for 2nd-Line mCRPC
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: This is the second trial assessing Novartis' BKM120 for prostate cancer. This Ph2 study will be conducted in two parts. The ultimate purpose is to determine PFS, response rate, disease control rate and OS of patients treated with the combination regimen and compare outcomes to historical results with single-agent cabazitaxel.

Sponsor: SCRI Development Innovations, LLC.

In a lead-in cohort, the feasibility and safety of administering BKM120 with a standard dose of cabazitaxel will be assessed. If safety is confirmed, a subsequent Phase II portion will assess the activity of the combination in patients with mCRPC previously treated with docetaxel. The treatment will consist of 3-week (21-day) cycles.

Recruitment: approx; 49
Timelines / Start date: March 2014 / Completion date: March 2016 / January 2017.
Location: Tennessee Oncology PLLC (USA)
Source: NCT02035124

item.title: re: Xofigo® Approved in the EU
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Xofigo® Approved in the EU 
Comment: Xofigo® 1000 kBq/ml, solution for injection has been granted MA less than 2 months after it gained a positive opinion from the EMA CHMP.  ...
Following EMA approval, Bayer HealthCare annouced UK launch of Xofigo® (radium-223 dichloride) solution for injection on 13th January 2014. Joe Hemphill (BU Head Speciality medicine, Bayer) stated " The launch and availability of Xofigo in the UK should be welcomed news for physicians and patients, who have been looking for new treatment options".
The technology appraisal has been sumbitted to NICE and first committee took place on 25 Sept 2013, however, outcome of the commitee could not be released as the marketing authorisation had not been granted at the time.
The expected date of issue is Feburary 2014.
Source: nice.org.uk, FirstWorld, PBR

item.title: New Deal To Focus On Increased Awareness & Adoption Of Intrathecal Therapies For Pain & Spasticity
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Medtronic and Mallinckrodt have entered into a multi-year agreement to advance the availability within the US of intrathecal therapeutics for the treatment of chronic pain and severe spasticity.
Nature of the Deal
Under the agreement, the two companies will focus on the development and testing of Mallinckrodt's future intrathecal products for use in Medtronic's SynchroMed Programmable Infusion System. As of today both companies manufacture and market intrathecal baclofen. Thus the nature of the future products that Mallinckrodt refers to has not been made clear.
The companies will also develop a joint marketing and sales programm to increase awareness and adoption of these drug delivery therapies. Intrathecal therapeutics use an implanted pump to deliver very small quantities of medication directly to a patient's spinal fluid.
The collaboration is intended to accelerate innovation and expand clinician and patient education regarding targeted delivery of drugs for the management of chronic disease.
Commenting on the deal Mark Trudeau, President & CEO of Mallinckrodt stated:-
"This agreement enables Mallinckrodt and Medtronic to focus on further pre-clinical, clinical and commercial aspects of intrathecal therapeutics, allowing each organisation to leverage their respective strengths, Mallinckrodt in specialty pharmaceuticals and Medtronic in terms of implantable drug delivery technology. Together, we will focus on advancing the development and delivery of therapeutic agents to serve patients suffereing from chronic pain and severe spasticity. We are excited about the future of our intrathecal product line and this agreement will enable us to deliver meaningful solutions to this market".
Source: www.malinckrodt.com
.
 
 

Comments
Comment: Mallinckrodt's presentation late yesterday at the JP Morgan H/C conference, didn't focus particularly on the Medtronix deal but did note how Gablofen, a pre-filled syringe preparation for intrathecal administration for spasticity is now its no 2 lead product and how intrathecal product development will be part of its growth strategy. Gablofen was acquired through the purchase of CNS Therapeutics in September 2012.
Mark Trudeau CEO focused on his intention to grow the specialty part of the group's business and how the group's pipeline would support this growth. Mid-term this is focused on Xartemis XR a combination opioid product. Longer-term, the focus move to the potential within the intrathecal space. Whilst not specfied we have identified a CNS Therapeutics patent covering a new and improved versions of baclofen WO-2010090765-A2 which offers improved stability a lower concentrations of degredation products.
Longer-term coporate growth he suggested will also focus on BD&L opportunities in CNS in adjacent channels and therapeutics including neurology and orthopaedics.

item.title: Sales in China Getting Better for GSK
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Chief Financial Officer Simon Dingemans said in an interview in San Francisco at JPMorgan H/C Conference that sales in China have improved since the third quarter of 2013 when drug revenu plunged as 61% vs a year earlier.
“The trend is definitely looking a bit more positive” since the quarter ended Sept. 30 ..."
“We can see the future opportunities to rebuild the business as and when we get to the other side of the inquiry. We’ll be working hard in 2014 to deliver that.”
... We have seen some stabilization, as I said, in the third quarter. In the back half of that quarter, it got a little bit better. Not dramatically better, but a bit better. And I don't want to comment on the fourth quarter yet other than to say that trend probably continued".
Source: Bloomberg; PharmaWorld10661: GSK's Chinese Sales Slump

Comment: According to feedback from the JP Morgan H/C Conference, a confident Pyott was telling FierceBiotech that he's ready to pay billions to cover the cost of a new acquisition in a move aimed at expanding the company's core research focus.
He reportedly said "We can afford to pay more than anyone else when it comes to adding new programs to the company's top fields and that reputation has earned us a first look at just about everything on the market.
The company has been carving out new fields in medical dermatology, neurology and urologics, all areas where it is reportedly willing to go out and take the extra steps needed to hunt down new programs of interest whether through a buyout,a licensing deal or partnership.

item.title: Stem Cell Trial In Post-Stroke Patients Initiated In China
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Neuralstem Inc has announced that the first patients has been treated in a phI/II tiral with its stem cell product NSI-566 to treat motor deficits from ischaemic stroke. The study is being undertaken in China.
The nature of the treatment
The stroke motor deficit trial is the first in which Neuralstem's spinal-cord derived stem cells are being transplanted directly into the patient's brain. They are placed near the stroke lesion, where it is hoped they will rebuild damaged neural circuitry and promote repair and recovery.
About the Trial

The Neuralstem China Phase I/II ischemic stroke trial will enroll up to 118 patients who have suffered an ischemic stroke and have chronic residual motor disorders, between four and 24 months after they have their strokes. The treatment will consist of one-time intracerebral injections of Neuralstem's NSI-566 stem cells into the stroke area using well-accepted stereotactic injection procedures.
Phase I will enroll up to 18 patients in three cohorts, each receiving an increasing dose, to determine the maximum safely-tolerated dose. Phase II, a multi-site, randomized and blinded study with a control group, will enroll up to 100 post-stroke patients. Half of the patients will receive a one-time treatment with the cells and physical therapy. The other half will receive only the physical therapy with no surgery. Measurements of outcome during the follow-up period will be blinded.The trial is expected to last two years.
 
Key comments concerning the trial

"We are excited to begin the first trial where the route of administration for our cells is injection into the brain," said Karl Johe, PhD, Neuralstem Chairman and Chief Scientific Officer. "We would like to thank our colleagues at BaYi, who are making this possible, and the patients who have volunteered for this ground-breaking trial. It is a crucial step forward for the company and the field at large, since optimizing cell therapy treatment for CNS indications will require delivering cells to the brain, as well as to the spinal cord."

"We are glad to be part of this world-leading clinical research project," said Professor Ruxiang Xu, Chief Physician, BaYi Brain Hospital. "BaYi Brain is a leading neurological medical institution in China with a state-of-the-art facility and advanced medical research and care staff. Through international collaborations, such as the clinical trial of neural stem cells for the treatment of ischemic stroke, we hope to be at the forefront of this new medical paradigm, treating multiple neurological diseases/disorders, such as ischemic stroke, spinal cord injury, ALS, and others, using the most advanced neural stem cells, developed by our U.S. partner, Neuralstem."


Source: www.neuralstem.com
 

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Nymox Close To Reporting PhII Results For NX-1207 In Low-Risk Prostate Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Nymox Pharmaceuticals announced that recruitment is being closed for the company's phII study of NX-1207 for low-risk localised, prostate cancer. Initial top line study results are expected to be available in around 6-8 weeks.
Study Design
The NX03-0040 study involves approximately 150 patients with low grade localized prostate cancer who are randomized to low or high single dose NX-1207 or to control (active surveillance with no drug or surgical or radiation treatment). Patients undergoing active surveillance in the trial also have the opportunity to receive NX-1207 after completion of their active surveillance portion of the trial.

The NX03-0040 study assesses the safety and efficacy of a single injection of NX-1207 in eradicating or shrinking low grade localized prostate cancer tumors by multiple clinical and laboratory measurements and blinded prostate biopsies at 6 weeks after treatment. Initial top-line results from trial NX03-0040 will be available soon after completion of the post-treatment biopsy assessment of the last patient randomized to drug.

Safety assessments of patients treated to date have been positive with no serious or unexpected adverse effects related to the drug, based on ongoing monitoring and safety committee reviews. In the study, NX-1207 is administered directly into the area of the prostate where the cancer was detected. The drug treatment is performed by a urologist in an office setting, and does not require anaesthesia, sedation, or catheterization. Treatment takes only a few minutes and involves minimal discomfort to the patient.

Developments Other Than Prostate Cancer

NX-1207 is also in late stage Phase 3 development in the U.S. for the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), In Europe a similar programme is being sponsored by Recordati S.p.A., the company's European licensing partner for the NX-1207 BPH indication.
Source: nymox.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Acorda At The JP Morgan H/C Conference. - Key Takeaways
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Acorda provided more details of its POC study with AMPYRA in post-stroke patients with walking deficits, confirmed positive discussions with the FDA and noted its intention to start a phIII study in Q214.

Commenting on the stroke opportunity with AMPURA, Ronald Cohen President & CEO stated "We had a successful proof-of-concept Phase II study that we announced in 2013. Just to give you the highlights on the outcome of major focus was walking in a timed walk, much as it was in MS. And you could see here even in this relatively small study with 80 total participants, a statistically significant improvement in walking speed in the dalfampridine group was seen.

And if you look at this as a responder analysis, which is also found in the label for AMPYRA in MS, where you – in this case, you look very simply at what percent of the people on drug versus placebo had certain threshold improvements in their walking speed greater than 10%, greater than 20%, 30%, 40% and 50%. And what you see here for both sides of this crossover study – by crossover, for those who are unfamiliar, we mean in the beginning some patients got drug, some got placebo and then they switched and we looked at them again in the second period.

So, regardless of which period you looked at, the patients on drug on average had more responders at every single threshold all the way to 50% and greater improvement. And this, again, is highly reminiscent of what we've seen in the MS story. We had said that we were going to meet with the FDA by the end of last year. Indeed, we did in December. We believe the meeting was highly constructive and the FDA made some recommendations to the design, which we're now integrating into the Phase III protocol. We'll be sending that back to them to get agreement and we plan to start the Phase III in the second quarter of this year.

item.title: Key Messages from Novartis Presentation at JP Morgan H/C Conference
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Ahead of the 2013 year-end-results planned on Jan. 29th, Joe Jimenez (CEO) reported on Novartis' performance for 9Mo2013, and on the three main objectives and priorities for 2014: extend lead in innovation, accelerate growth and drive productivity. He ended his presentation with a 'couple of thoughts on why everybody should own a piece of the company'.
  • 16 approvals across US, EU and Japan
  • 4% net sales growth
  • good progress in productivity ($2 bln)
  • good performance in emerging markets (+10%), lead by Russia and China. Management reported a 'little bit of slowdown in China, based on what is happening in the country'
  • good progress in pipeline development (AIN457, secukinumab shows superiority in over Enbrel with a very strong safety profile. Filing in the US and EU in Q4:13. " ... So we could be expecting approval this current fiscal year".
Jimenez outlined three key elements of the plan:
Managing Portfolio Actively
Last summer, the company started a review of all its businesses with market attractiveness, competitive position and synergistic fit with the rest of portfolio as main selection criteria.
Delivering Synergy Between Division
R&D synergy - Collaboration between Sandoz and the Oncology Pharma Division was highlighted : ' ... the oncology development group is running some of the biosimilars trials for the Sandoz division and it is more collaboration like this that is going to untap value and give Novartis competitive advantage particularly in the area of R&D'.
Revenue synergies - with a program called'Customers First', being 'go to market as one company, one face to the trade'.
Cost synergies across divisions - management said ' ... We have organized our procurement group globally so no matter what division you are in at Novartis you have a central procurement group that is group wide'.
Greater Comittment to Shareholder Return

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Sanofi Acquires 12% of Alnylam
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Sanofi will buy a 12% stake in Alnylam for $700m deepening its already existing partnership with the company. It will pay $80 per share representing a 27% premium over the past 30-days share price. The siRNA & drug delivery technology Alnylam has deployed for its products was in-licensed from Tekmira, a company now developing its lead product for NET & adrenal cancer.
Background
Sanofi's earlier partnership with Alnylam started in 2012. Attracted by its RNAi interfernce technology, the two companies agreed to work together to develop Alnylam's lead product patisiran, which is currently in late-stage development of transthyretin (TTR)-familial amyloid polyneuropathy.
Sanofi originally had rights to this product in Japan and the broader Asia-Pacific region. These rights have now been extended to all markets outside of the US & Europe.
Additional Opportunities To Which Sanofi Now Has Rights
Additionally it has gained right to three other products in the Alnylam portfolio including one drug for familiail cardiomyopathy and another for the treatment of hemophilia. The former will be co-developed and co-marketed in North America and Europe/
Implications For Other Companies
The expanded relationship adds credibility to Alnylam's technology, a technology it partnered from another small biotechnology company Tekmira. The latter is developing a polo-like kinase drug to treat neuroendocrine tumours and adrenal cancer (see slides below).
Source: www.sanofi.com & www.tekmira.com

item.title: Lexicon Restructures As CEO Steps Down
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Lexicon has announced the departure of its CEO Arthur Sands and a 45% reduction in its workforce as it moves its focus away from drug discovery to development of its late-stage products.
115 positions will be cut in R&D to reduce costs by $14m in 2014 net of severance costs and some other charges and by $20m annually thereafter.
Arthur Sands intends to develop a succession plan with the boaord to identify a new CEO and will step down once his successor is appointed.
Next Steps
The company intends to focus on the late stage development of its diabetes drug and LX1032 for carcinoid syndrome, to more effectively advance these late stage programms and to prepare for commercialisation.
Source: www.lexicon .com

item.title: Sinclair IS Pharma Buys Perfectha™ Dermal Fillers Through the Acquisition of ObvieLine Lab. SA
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The company has entered into agreements to acquire the global rights to Perfectha™ dermal fillers through the acquisition of Obvieline Laboratories SA, and has also entered into agreements to acquire distribution rights principally in Brazil and Russia from Pharmavital SA (Obvieline's parent company) for a total of up to €32.2 million in cash with an initial payment of €10.0 million.
Rationale for Sinclair
Perfectha™ acquisition gives Sinclair a global facial aesthetics presence

· Strong sales in Asia, Russia and Brazil

· Opportunity to leverage Sinclair EU5 sales forces

· Significant earnings accretion expected from 2014/15

Perfectha™ brand
5 gel products which reduce folds, lines and wrinkles in different facial areas.
It is expected that the Perfectha™ range will be extended to include a pre-mixed lidocaine (anaesthetic) product in late 2014.
Perfectha's E-brid technology requires lower injected volumes and is easy for clinicians to inject.
Perfectha™ Revenues
€5.2 million and profit before tax and exceptional items of €0.4 million in the year ended 31 December 2012 and over 60% revenue growth to approximately €8.4 million (unaudited) in its financial year to 31 December 2013, which included approximately €3.6 million from Asia.
Around 90% of Perfectha™ 2013 revenues came from emerging markets with the balance from Western Europe.
Sinclair Pharma SnapShot
Sinclair IS Pharma is an international speciality pharma company, with corporate headquarters in London, UK and operations headquarters in Paris, France.
  • Focus on Dermatology
  • Drive operating leverage in the business through volume growth using European infrastructure
  • Create strong organic sales growth from fast growing Emerging Markets
Aesthetic Products http://www.sinclairispharma.com/our-products/aesthetic.aspx
ObvieLine Laboratories SA
Engages in research, development, manufacturing, and distribution of Hyaluronic Acid (HA) derma fillers.
The company was founded in 2005 and is based in Dardilly, France.

item.title: ESS Has Started to Evaluate Safety/Efficacy of Degarelix with Ipilimumab for Castration-sensitive Oligometastatic PCa
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Sponsored by the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center and in collaboration with Ferring, the objective of the Ph2 is to find out what effects taking ipilimumab with degarelix before surgery (radical prostatactomy) followed by more degarelix and ipilimumab after RP, will have on the condition. PE will measure undetectable PSA.
* oligometastatic = (≤5 lesions).
Study Details NCT02020070
Timelines
Completion date: Dec 2018
Recruitment
Approx 53 men with castration-sensitive oligometastatic prostate cancer who have not received primary local therapy (radiation or surgery), and no more than 2 months of prior ADT.
Location
MSK Cancer Center (PI: Howard Scher, MD)

item.title: France OKs Use of Sativex for MS Spasticity
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Sativex, a cannabis-based mouth spray, is indicated for spasticity associated with multiple sclerosis (MS). Alongside its Q3:13 financial results, management reported that " ...Germany is the largest market for Sativex, and we've now been able to successfully renegotiate an acceptable price in Germany. And the underlying volume growth is proceeding well, up nearly one-third year on year".
Background in France
October 2013 - Successful closing of Mutual Recognition Procedure for Sativex in France.
US Situation
August 2013: GW opened a Ph3 IND application with the FDA to conduct a pivotal efficacy and safety clinical program to evaluate Sativex® for the treatment of MS spasticity. GW expects the U.S. Phase 3 trial to commence in 2014
Cancer Pain Indication
Currently in Phase 3 clinical trials as a treatment for cancer pain. This represents the lead target indication for the product in the U.S.
Source: GW Pharm.; ThomsonOne

item.title: Tokai to Initiate Ph3 of Galeterone for CRPC
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Tokai has reported that the results from the ongoing ARMOR2 Ph2 trial will be used to define the Phase 3 trials planned for initiation in the second half of 2014. New data from this Ph2 trial will be presented by the co-investigator at the 2014 ASCO GU in San Francisco.
Poster
Date & Time: Thursday, January 30, 2014 from 11:30 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. and 5:15 p.m. to 6:45 p.m. (PT)
Title: ARMOR2: Galeterone in progressive CRPC patients who have failed oral therapy
Abstract: #71 Poster Board: E6 Session: General Poster Session A – Prostate Cancer
Location: Golden Gate Hall
Presenter: Mary-Ellen Taplin, M.D., associate professor of medicine, director of genitourinary clinical research, Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, Harvard Medical School, and co-principal investigator of ARMOR2
ARMOR Ph2 Details - NCT01709734

item.title: New CEO at Galderma North America
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Stuart Raetzman is appointed Chief Executive Officer of Galderma Laboratories, L.P. and Vice President North America, effective March 1, 2014. He previously worked for Allergan, Chiron Vision and for over 20 years with Alcon lab., a division of Novartis. North America represents roughly 50% of the company total sales.
Business
Has led:
  • teams in the U.S. and on international assignment in Europe, the Middle East and Africa (EURMEA).
  • small, multi‐functional executive level teams to develop Board of Director level strategic plans. These teams included the heads of R&D, manufacturing and finance. He has also led large commercial organizations.
  • the Alcon U.S. organization with 2,500 associates and in his latest role, he led a team of more than 4,000 associates across EURMEA.
Education
Holds a bachelor’s degree from the McCombs School of Business at the University of Texas and attended the Advanced Management Program at Harvard.
Source: Galderma

item.title: PARP Inhibitors Are Bouncing Back in Oncology
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: PARP inhibitors, once the most promising class of anti-cancer agents, experienced a few disappointing set backs in 2011 and are now possibly staging a comeback. The field is fizzling and rejuvated with four companies including AstraZeneca, Tesaro, BioMarin, and Clovis, in the process of launching pivotal trials.
Beginning in the 1990s, companies began developing PARP inhibitors as chemopotentiators because many chemotherapy drugs cause DNA damage that is repaired by PARP mediated DNA repair. Despite of its promising anti-tumour activity, they are highly toxic. In 2005, two breakthrough Nature papers published promising results of PARP inhibitors in cancer cells with pre-existing DNA repair defects – mutation in BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes. Positive Phase II results of iniparib in triple negative breast cancer patients (TNBC) generated enormous excitement as it featured an oral plenary presentation at 45th ASCO meeting (2009) – combination of iniparib with chemotherapy doubled PFS without inducing myelosuppression. In 2009, Sanofi-aventis agreed to pay up to $500 million for BiPar Sciences, Inc. in order to gain development right for iniparib. At the time of the BiPar acquisition, iniparib was viewed as the most advanced PARP inhibitor in the field. The elation was short-lived as Sanofi reported disappointing negative phase III results of iniparib in 2011. In December 2011, AstraZeneca discontinued development of their PARP inhibitor – olaparib - for ovarian cancer. This has led many observers to give up and the excitement around PARP inhibitors “came to a screeching halt”.
“I think we've made that turnaround. A lot has been going on to get us excited again in this field” Dr. Susan Domchek (an oncologist and breast cancer researcher at the University of Pennsylvania
Independent investigators confirmed that iniparib and its metabolite were not functional PARP inhibitors. Sanofi also acknowledged the recent research demonstrating iniparib can’t inhibit PARP at pharmacological concentration. AstraZeneca then re-examined the olaparib from trial 19 and discovered an emerging trend towards improved overall survival in BRCA mutant patient group – specifically patients with germline or somatic tumour BRCA mutations (median PFS of 11.2 months compared to 4.3 months for placebo).
“Stopping olaparib development was just a big mistake. It allowed competitors to move forward quite quickly.” Dr. Jonathan Ledermann (leading investigator and oncologist in UCL Cancer Institute)
Table below outlined the five active PARP inhibitors currently under clinical development. Three companies – AZstraZeneca, Tesaro and Clovis – are testing their candidates as a single agent for maintenance therapy with the goal of delaying or preventing disease relapse following chemotherapy treatment in ovarian cancer. So far the pharmacological properties suggest little differentiation amongst these candidates, they do have somewhat different specificity profile - while they all target PARP1 and PARP 2, they do target other PARP family members, of which have unknown functions. As tolerability is key in the maintenance setting, off-target toxicity may vary enough to make a difference. In addition, the success will also be dependent on their target patient population as three companies differ in their strategy for target patient population. AstraZeneca targets the narrowest but least risky population with serous ovarian cancers that harbour BRCA mutations only. Tesaro targets a wider patient pool including all relapsed patients with high grade serous ovarian cancer regardless of BRCA status. Clovis targets the same patient population as Tesaro but with additional effort to identify the subpopulation most likely to benefit from rucaparib via collaboration with cancer genomics company.
.
A recent preclinical study published in Cancer Discovery suggests a newly discovered function of PARP-1 could be the key to more effective therapeutics to treat advanced prostate cancer patients - functions of PARP-1 were found not only include DNA damage repair but also androgen receptor (AR) regulation in advanced prostate cancer growth and progression. Researchers believe that the dual functions of PARP-1—as both a regulator of AR as well as critical for DNA damage repair—could be leveraged for therapeutic benefit. Using various in vitro and in vivo model systems, the researchers found that PARP-1 activity is required for AR function and is increased in castrate-resistant prostate cancer.
“These findings introduce a paradigm shift with regard to PARP-1 in prostate cancer, and provide the basis for new therapies that could help a whole population of cancer patients who have little options.” Dr. Knudsen
Other rationale for clinical development of PARP inhibitors includes combination with radiotherapy. Dr. Anthony Chalmers discussed the scientific rationale behind the combination strategy of PARP inhibitors with radiation therapy in one of the scientific symposiums during ESMO 2013. A variety of in vitro models demonstrated PARP inhibitors increased radiosensitivity (~30-50%) and similarly in vivo. Up to date, olaparib, veliparib, and niraparib are being explored in early clinical development in combination with radiotheraoy (Phase I-II).
Scientific Background
Poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase 1 (PARP-1) is a DNA-binding enzyme that is activated by DNA breaks, converting them into an intracellular signal to facilitate the access of base excision/single strand break repair proteins and activating these repair enzymes. PARP inhibitors have been developed to investigate the role of PARP-1 in cell biology and to overcome DNA repair-mediated resistance of cancer cells to cytotoxic therapy. Since the early benzamide inhibitors of the 1980s PARP inhibitors, developed through structure-activity relationships and crystal structure-based drug design, that are 1,000x more potent have been identified. These novel PARP inhibitors have been shown to enhance the antitumour activity of temozolomide (a DNA-methylating agent), topoisomerase poisons and ionising radiation in advanced pre-clinical studies and are now under clinical evaluation. PARP inhibitors can also selectively kill cells and tumours with homozygous defects in the hereditary breast cancer genes, BRCA1 and BRCA2. The one common dose-limiting disadvantage is myelosuppression, and a more potent compound could mean a lower does can be effective.
Key Challenges
Several PARP inhibitors are under investigation and it is anticipated that this novel class of compounds will ultimately receive regulatory approval in subsets of cancers. AstraZeneca, Tesaro and Clovis are focusing their effort to the maintenance strategy as the fast route to FDA/EMA approval. Companion test of this agents need to be validated and lack of predictive biomarkers remain the key to the success for PARP inhibitors in the future.
References:
  1. PARP inhibitors bounce back. Ken Garber Nature Reviews Drug Discovery Vol 12 Oct 2013
  2. PARP inhibitors for BRCA 1/2 mutation-associated and BRCA-like malignancies. J-m, Lee, J.L. Ledermann & E.C. Kohn Annals of Oncology Vol 25 2014
  3. Poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase inhibition as a model for synthetic lethality in developing radiation oncology targets. Chalmers AJ, Lakshman M, Chan N, Bristow RG. Semin Radiat Oncol. 2010 Oct;20(4):274-81.
  4. ESMO 2013 Scietific Symposium: Exploiting defective DNA damage response pathways in tumours

item.title: Forest Acquires Aptalis for $2.9bln
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Forest lab has acquired Aptalis, a privately held U.S. based specialty Gastrointestinal and Cystic Fibrosis company, for $2.9bln. The transaction is expected to close in H1:14. Key slides from the Forest Investor Webcast are provided below.
- deal immediately accretive to non-GAAP EPS
- synergy
- ideal fit for Forest because of Aptalis strong product offerings in two therapeutic franchises that are complementary to Forest - GI in the US. and Canada and Cystic Fibrosis in EU.
- to offset the loss of Lexapro and Namenda patents, its top profit drivers (respectively 69% and 84% of current product revenues).
Sales: $687.9 million for the fiscal year ended September 30, 2013.
Aptalis has a number of drugs that treat cystic fibrosis and gastrointestinal disorders, and sells its products primarily in Canada, US and EU.
  • Sales of the top three products in the U.S. - Canasa, Carafate, and Zenpep - accounted for more than 60% of company sales in FY2013
  • International sales accounted for approximately 15% of revenues.
  • Aptalis Pharmaceutical Technologies, a third party delivery technology provider and drug manufacturer, accounted for approximately 15% of revenues.
Products Portfolio @ http://www.aptalispharma.com/featured-products
Main products include:
  • Namenda, a N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) antagonist for the treatment of moderate to severe dementia of the Alzheimer's type;
  • Bystolic, a beta-blocker for the treatment of hypertension;
  • Linzess, a guanylate cyclase type-C receptor agonist for the once-daily treatment for men and women suffering from IBS-C or CIC;
  • Tudorza, a long-acting antimuscarinic agent for the long-term maintenance treatment of bronchospasm associated with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), including chronic bronchitis and emphysema;
  • Viibryd, a SSRI and a 5-HT1A receptor partial agonist for the treatment of adults with depressive disorder (MDD).
TPG has been exploring the sale of Aptalis since August last year (see GastroEnterology1906: TPG Is Exploring The Sale of Specialty Drugmaker Aptalis).
In October, Aptalis appointed underwriters for an initial IPO after efforts to sell the compnay failed (GastroEnterology1926: Aptalis Hires Banks for an IPO).
Source: ThomsonOne; Forest Lab.; Aptalis

item.title: Allergan Secures Agreement With Medytox
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Allergan today announced that it has closed the license agreement which was previously announced on September 25, 2013 with Medytox.
Deal Terms
Under the terms of the agreement, Allergan will pay Medytox an upfront cash payment of U.S. $65 million within seven business days of closing and Medytox has granted Allergan exclusive rights, worldwide outside of Korea, to develop and, if approved, commercialize certain neurotoxin product candidates currently in development, including a potential liquid-injectable product.
Pursuant to the agreement, Allergan has also agreed to make additional contingent payments, including up to an aggregate of U.S. $116.5 million upon achieving certain development milestones, up to an aggregate of U.S. $180.5 million upon achieving certain commercialization milestones, and royalties on product sales.
Source: allergan.com

item.title: Valeant's Aspiration To Rank Amongst The Top 5
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: During today's call, Michael Pearson Valeant's CEO stated his ambition for Valeant to be ranked amongst the world's top five pharmaceutical companies by market capitalisation by the end of 2016, largely through acquisitions, so called merger of equals as well as smaller deals. Possibly given the number of positive references to aesthetics and size relative to Allergan, we might expect further deals within this market segment.
Commenting on its business prospects Pearson made the following key comments:-
"We are extremely excited about the opportunities that we believe lie ahead for Valeant in 2014 and we thought it’d be helpful to outline our priorities for the year. Firstly we expect to continue our strong organic growth performance and plan to drive growth in all of our businesses. All of our businesses are expected to grow in 2014 and most of our businesses are expected to grow double digit including our aesthetics, contact lens, consumer, neurology, and oral health in the U.S. and all of our emerging market businesses. In 2014, we see additional opportunity to grow U.S. aesthetics and oral health businesses by significantly expanding the sales force".
"In 2013, the Medicis aesthetic portfolio achieved record sales. By expanding the sales force to approximately 200, we hope to build long-term partnerships with a larger group of doctors and with the acquisition of Solta and our continued relationship with Mentor, we will have the broadest and most attractive portfolio of products in the market. Since we acquired OraPharma in Q2 of 2012, the business is growing each quarter greater than 10% even though we call on a very small percentage of dentists. By increasing the number of reps by approximately 50%, we will be able to reach a greater number of dentists and significantly increase revenue."
During the Q/A he stated:-
"We’re very pleased with our aesthetics business. As I mentioned there are injectables Restylane, Perlane, Sculptra, Dysport, overall grew over 30% year-on-year. In terms of the economics, we’re selling on average about $2.5 million per sales rep. So that leads to very attractive economics for us. But we were very undersized relative to Allergan. We had a roughly 90 reps. They’re closer to 200, that’s why we’re increasing our field force for injectibles up to similar amount as Allergan because we think with the product line that we now have especially with the addition of Solta, we have the products and portfolio. And a lot of doctors encourage us to get into the medical devices area and are quite pleased on that, that will now be adding this set of products to our current products. So, aesthetics continues to be better than we’ve even hoped when we purchased Medicis."
Source: www.valeant.com

item.title: Richter Expands into Four More Countries in Latin America
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Richter aims to tap into fast-growing markets for its gynea portfolio (which represents a third of its total sales). The company declined to name the countries involved.
CEO Erik Bogsch, in charge at Richter since 1992, told Reuters that "... this will probably also take the form of joint ventures (and) we are in talks about this ... "
Oncology9379: Richter to Establish Strategic Position in Brazil for its Female HC Business.
Source: ThomsonOne

item.title: Neurocrine to Finalize Ph3 Draft Protocol with FDA for its Tardive Dyskinesia Drug
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: NBI-98854, a small molecule VMAT2 inhibitor, showed a statistically significant and clinically meaningful reduction in tardive dyskinesia symptoms in the Ph2b Kinect 2 study. The company now anticipates filing the Ph3 protocol with the FDA in the first half of 2014. Management reported to be in 'contact with numerous interested partners'.
Chris O'Brien, CMO, announced during a January 6th webcast that : " ... The Kinect 3 study will be a Phase 3 study. So all the work that we've been -- we've actually been working diligently in the background, planning for all the work that goes into education and recruitment efforts because it's a big project ramping up for the next study.
The Kinect 3 study was designed to be a 12-week study, was designed to be either a fixed-dose or a titration study depending on the Kinect 2 results. It was designed to pool schizophrenic, schizoaffective, bipolar, and depression patients. It was designed to look at probably a 50-milligram and a 75-milligram dose. So in fact, there's not really a lot has changed.
The only difference is to be worked out with the FDA, is it one study or is it two studies for Phase 3? Is it 6 weeks of placebo or is it 12 weeks of placebo? It's going to be a 12-week study no matter what, and we only need to finish -- we need to finish our PK/PD work to decide what the final dose is for the titration design. So it's actually not a big leap. The biggest leap is -- has got to be video AIMS scored by movement disorder neurologists with this consensus adjudication process".
Primary Endpoint: AIMS

item.title: Brazil's National Supplementary Health Agency Orders Health Plans to Cover 37 Oral Oncology Drugs
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The 37 oral oncology drugs are those for treating some of the most common cancers, including those affecting the stomach, liver, intestine, kidney, testes, uterus, ovary, and breast. Specific products that are on the list include among others Johnson & Johnson 's Zytiga (abiraterone), which costs BRL11,000 per pack.
The National Supplementary Health Agency's new list of obligatory medicines, tests and procedures means that coverage will be available even earlier than had previously been stipulated under a new law that had been approved in October 2013, but which is not due to take effect until May this year.
The scope of the new law provides for the obligatory inclusion not only of the 37 oral drugs specified by the ANS, but also other types of drugs.
The provision of oral cancer medicines has long been demanded by users of health plans and by doctors, but up until now patients have had to go to court to obtain treatment with these drugs. Unlike traditional forms of chemotherapy, oral cancer drugs have a comparatively low side-effect profile and can be administered at home, avoiding the need for hospital treatment.
However, although the inclusion of the 37 oral drugs in the new ANS list has been widely welcomed, the ANS has received criticism over the fact that the use of genetic tests can only be requested by specialist geneticist doctors. The fact that there are only around 200 such doctors throughout Brazil will severely limit the use of these tests.
Source: IHS GlobalInsight

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: New CSO at Aeterna Zentaris
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Dr Richard Sachse will be responsible for all areas of the global R&D activities. Before joining Aeterna Zentaris, he was Vice President, Head of Global Translational Medicine at Boehringer Ingelheim.
Education
Dr. Sachse holds a degree in medicine from the Friedrich-Alexander-University Erlangen, in Germany, and a board certification in Clinical Pharmacology. With more than 20 years experience as a physician and scientist, he has extensive expertise in a variety of different therapeutic areas including endocrinology and oncology. In addition to registration studies, he is especially experienced in the design and implementation of translational programs to bridge research programs to the clinic, as well as in the design and implementation of clinical pharmacology programs, including all required profiling studies and activities, enabling successful registration of products at the international level.
Professional Activities
In 2007, after a merger, he became Senior Director, Head of Experimental Medicine, at UCB in Belgium, where he managed the implementation of novel biomarkers in clinical development to provide data supporting identification of appropriate target indication and target population.
In 2010, Dr. Sachse became Vice President, Head of Global Translational Medicine at Boehringer Ingelheim.

item.title: Global Reach Of Indian Pharmaceutical Companies
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Yesterday's FT highlights the growing influence of Asia in the global pharmaceutical market, noting how India is now producing as many medicines for the UK as those manufactured within the UK itself. Indian factories are producing the finished form of 3,685 drugs compared with 3,815 made within the UK
This statistics from the UK MHA, places Indian manufactureres ahead of all other foreign producers including companies located in Germany, Ireland and France.

The British statistics mirrors high and rising penetration rates by Indian producers in other industrialised countries around the world and has raised some concerns over quality as manufacturing shifts beyond national boundaries. However, whilst there were concerns with 9-10 manufactureres over the last 2 years as a proportion of the total no undertaken this is similar to that observed in other parts of the world.

Meanwhile, a separate report by a legal IP consultancy notes an increase in annual patent filings by Indian companies over the past decade from 160 to 450 per year. Most are focused on manufacturing procedures for drugs, new formulations and crystalline forms of existing drugs rather than NCEs.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Natpara (rhPTH) Granted Orphan Drug Status In Europe
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: NPS Pharmaceuticals announced on Friday that the European Commission has granted ODS status to its recombinant parathyroid hormone Natpara for the treatment of hypoparathyroidism.
Commenting on this development Francois Nader MD, President and CEO of NPS Pharmaceuticals stated "We are very pleased that Natpara has received orphan drug status in the EU. As a global rare disease biopharmaceutical company, this aligns with our commitment to deliver innovative therapies that transform the lives of patients around the world. Hypoparathyroidism patients face a significant burden of disease given the multitude of physical, cognitive, and emotional symptoms associated with this disorder. Natpara could be the first PTH replacement therapy to treat this condition."

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Israel Adds Janssen's Zytiga to Healthcare Basket
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Zytiga is part of a list of 83 drugs and technologies to be proposed for reimbursement approval by the Public Committee for the Update of the Basket. These recommendations require the approval of the National Health Council and the Israeli cabinet.
The list cover a diverse range of indications, including allergies, cardiovascular, dermatology, endocrinology, food supplements, gastroenterology, metabolic diseases, neurology, oncology, respiratory, rheumatology, transplants, and urology. Estimates put forward by Minister of Health Yael German suggest that these medicines could benefit approximately two million Israelis.
Source: IHS GlobalInsight

item.title: China to Introduce Corruption "Blacklist" of Drugmakers and Device Manufacturers
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Lists of offending manufacturers, agents and individuals will be published online from the beginning of March 2014.
The companies named on the list once will be banned for 2 years from selling within the region where they were implicated, while those appearing on the list twice in 5 years will be banned nationally, also for 2 years.
In addition, any medical practitioners who receive bribes will be punished.
Source: FirstWord

item.title: Long-term Extension Study of Lexicon's Telotristat Etiprate for Carcinoid Syndrome
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The objective of the Ph3 TELEPATH trial is to evaluate the long-term safety and tolerability of the drug (dose: 250mg/500mg). PE will measure incidente of treatment-emergent AEs.
Trial Details
Recruitment: n=160
  • Ongoing participation in a Phase 2 (LX1606.1-202-CS, LX1606.1-203-CS) or Phase 3 (LX1606.1-301-CS, LX1606.1-303-CS) study
Location: one site in Germany
Completion date is planned for Dec 2014.
Source: NCT02026063

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Focused Cold Therapy Tested for Upper Limb Spasticity (ULS) and Occipital Neuralgia
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Myoscience is currently conducting two small POC studies to evaluate its Cryo-Touch III Device. In the ULS trial, PE will measure improvement of hypertonia of the upper arm. In the other study, PE will measure the reduction in either pain frequency or severity associated with the condition. Focused Cold Therapy is currently approved in EU and Canada for temporary wrinkle reduction, temporary pain reduction and treatment of dermatologic conditions.
Upper Limb Spasticity Trial
Recruitment: n=20 male or female, 18 years of age and older.
  • Trial participants must have a confirmed diagnosis that results in spasticity involving muscle innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve (MCN).
  • Any medications must be maintained on a stable schedule for at least two weeks prior to treatment. No washout period is allowed.
  • Must have an average score on the Modified Ashworth Scale for Spasticity of ≥ 2 over the last 30 days in the elbow

Location: 2 sites in the US

Source: NCT01863901

Occipital Neuralgia Study

Recruitment: n=30 male or female, 18 years of age and older.

  • A confirmed diagnosis of occipital neuralgia (unilateral or bilateral) .
  • Any medication must be maintained on a stable schedule for at least two weeks prior to treatment. No washout period is allowed.
  • Must have an average score for pain of ≥ 4/10 Visual Analog Scale (VAS) over the last 7 days
Location: 3 sites in the US
Source: NCT01753765

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: EMA Accepts Otsuka's MAA for Polycystic Kidney Disease Drug
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: If approved by the Agency, tolvaptan would become the 1st pharmaceutical therapy in Europe for patients with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). In August 2013, the EMA’s Committee for Orphan Medicinal Products (COMP) granted tolvaptan orphan drug designation for the treatment of ADPKD.
What is ADPKD
ADPKD is an inherited genetic disease that causes cyst growth in the kidneys, which gradually impairs their functioning. There is no current pharmaceutical treatment option.
The condition is estimated to affect approximately 200,000 people in Europe
Drug Mini Profile
MoA: Tolvaptan is a selective V2 vasopressin receptor antagonist.
Status: In Japan, the application for ADPKD is currently under review. In the US, Otsuka and FDA have been working together to determine the most appropriate path forward to allow tolvaptan to be available for patients suffering from ADPKD.
Source: Otsuka
